column1: Moore is located just south of Oklahoma City and north of Norman
column2: in central Oklahoma. According to the United States Census Bureau
column3: the city has a total area of 22.2 square miles (57.4 km2)
column4: of which 21.8 square miles (56.5 km2) is land and 0.35 square miles (0.9 km2)
column6: is water.The city lies in the Sandstone Hills region of Oklahoma

column1: Moore has a humid subtropical climate with frequent variations in weather during part of the year and consistently hot summers. Prolonged and severe droughts often lead to wildfires and heavy rainfall often leads to flash flooding and flooding. Consistent winds
column2: usually from the south or south-southeast during the summer
column3: help temper the hotter weather. Consistent northerly winds during the winter can intensify cold periods. Severe ice storms and snowstorms happen sporadically during the winter.

column1: The Oklahoma City metropolitan area (of which Moore is a part) is located in Tornado Alley and is subject to frequent and severe tornadoes and hailstorms
column2: making it one of the most tornado-prone major metropolitan areas in the world.

column1: Moore itself has seen nine tornadoes between 1998 and 2015
column2: three of them big enough to claim lives and cause catastrophic damage. The city of Moore was damaged by significant tornadoes on October 4
column8: with weaker tornadoes striking at other times
column11: 2015. Moore is located in Tornado Alley
column12: a colloquial term for the area of the United States where tornadoes are most frequent. About 20 tornadoes occurred in the immediate vicinity of Moore from 1890 to 2013. The most significant tornadoes to hit Moore occurred in 1893

column1: During the tornado outbreak on May 3
column3: a tornado hit Moore and nearby areas. The tornado
column4: which was rated an F5 on the Fujita scale
column5: was the most costly tornado in history at the time (not adjusted for changes in inflation and population). The tornado had an approximate recorded wind speed of 301 mph (484 km/h) as sampled by mobile Doppler radar
column6: the highest wind speed ever recorded on Earth. It left a swath of destruction over 1 mile (1.6 km) wide at times
column7: and 38 miles (60 km) long. It killed a total of 36 people in the Oklahoma City metropolitan area. This was the deadliest F5 tornado recorded since the Delhi
column8: Louisiana tornado in 1971 until this mark was eclipsed by several tornadoes in 2011.

column3: parts of Moore and neighboring Newcastle and southern Oklahoma City
column4: were affected by a violent tornado. Classified as EF5 on the Enhanced Fujita scale
column5: it had estimated wind speeds of 200–210 mph (320–340 km/h)
column6: a maximum width of 1.3 miles (2 km)
column7: and a path length of 17 miles (30 km). Entire subdivisions were destroyed; the tornado struck Briarwood and Plaza Towers elementary schools in Moore while school was in session. The Oklahoma Medical Examiner's office reported that 24 people were killed
column10: were treated at hospitals following the tornado. It was the deadliest U.S. tornado since the Joplin
column11: Missouri tornado that killed 158 people in 2011.

column1: The only post-secondary school physically within Moore is the Randall University which has an enrollment of about 225.  Moore's neighbor immediately to the south is Norman
column3: home of the University of Oklahoma. The Moore Norman Technology Center is a public career and technology education center. Its campuses however are outside of Moore in Norman and South Oklahoma City.

column1: Two media outlets focus on the Moore community. Moore Monthly publishes a free monthly print publication while its website provides daily stories and videos about Moore
column2: Norman and south Oklahoma City. The other media outlet is the Moore American.

column1: The City of Moore has funded the construction of a memorial to honor America's veterans and their families. The city renamed JD Estates Park to Veterans Memorial Park
column2: and a memorial was constructed at the park entrance.

column1: The main feature of the memorial is a 15-foot (4.6 m) black granite obelisk that has the inscription
column2: "May this hallowed ground honor the sacrifice of America's finest veterans
column3: civilians
column6: and future. We will never forget." Another major feature of the memorial are five black granite tablets with the seal of the five branches of the American armed forces. At the center of the memorial is a flag plaza with a 30-foot (9.1 m) pole for the American flag and two 25-foot (7.6 m) poles for the Oklahoma flag and the POW/MIA flag. The flag plaza is surrounded by a polished concrete walking area with a stained five-pointed star stretching the entire width and height of the walking area.

column1: A committee was formed to plan the second phase of the Moore Veterans Memorial. A campaign to sell bricks to be placed in the memorial was completed in early 2009. Over 190 bricks were purchased by supporters from the community and surrounding areas. The bricks were placed in the Memorial Wall and Phase II was completed in May 2009.
The Soldiers' Memorial was dedicated on May 15
column2: 2010. It consists of four carved wooden soldiers representing the four major wars since the end of World War I. They include World War II
column3: Korea
column5: and the Afghanistan/Iraq War.After being destroyed by the May 2013 tornado
column6: the park won the title of "America's Favorite Park" in an online competition sponsored by Coca-Cola
column7: beating out numerous other parks from around the country. First prize was a $100
column9: which was combined with other funds to cover the estimated $200
column10: 000 in rebuilding expenses. The first steps toward rebuilding began in November 2013
column11: during a groundbreaking ceremony and the awarding of the grant to Mayor Glenn Lewis. The park's playgrounds are now open to the public.
